content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE HIPC TRUST FUND. Authorization is given to appropriate $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 to fund the United States share of the additional financing needs of the current HIPC program. Additional funding is authorized upon improvement of the Enhanced HIPC Initiative, as determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Indebted Poor Countries Trust Fund, administered by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, provides additional financing for the Enhanced HIPC Initiative. SEC. 2. IMPROVEMENT OF THE ENHANCED HIPC INITIATIVE. Title XVI of the International Financial Institutions Act is amended to include a new section titled "IMPROVEMENT OF THE ENHANCED HIPC INITIATIVE." The Secretary of the Treasury will work with international institutions to modify the Enhanced HIPC Initiative to increase resources for poverty reduction in heavily indebted poor countries. This includes adjusting debt reduction based on export levels and revenues. The reduction approved for a country eligible for debt relief under the Enhanced HIPC Initiative aims to decrease the outstanding debt to not more than 150 percent of annual exports and limit annual debt payments to 10 percent or less. The Enhanced HIPC Initiative aims to reduce a country's debt to not more than 5 percent of annual current revenues or a percentage of gross national product. International financial institutions should prioritize using their own resources for financing the initiative. Debt cancellation under the Enhanced HIPC Initiative is not tied to policies that worsen poverty or harm the environment, such as imposing user fees on essential services for the poor or increasing costs for those with incomes below $2.00 per day. The text chunk discusses restrictions on foreign government policies that could negatively impact access to clean drinking water for individuals with incomes below $2.00 per day and undermine workers' rights. Foreign government policies that disqualify countries from debt cancellation under the Enhanced HIPC Initiative include supporting terrorism, gross human rights violations like torture, and recent designations. Countries designated as 'Tier 3' in the Department of State's Trafficking in Persons Report are ineligible for debt cancellation under the Enhanced HIPC Initiative unless they commit to using the financial benefits for poverty alleviation programs. The Enhanced HIPC Initiative aims to provide debt cancellation to countries for poverty alleviation programs, including education, nutrition, and health services, environmental protection, transparent governance, and public participation. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Arms Export Control Act related to cooperation with the United States on combating international terrorism. Amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Arms Export Control Act require cooperation with the United States on combating international terrorism. Amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Arms Export Control Act now require cooperation with the United States in combating international terrorism, including the transfer of chemical or biological weapons by foreign persons. SEC. 4. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit reports on the progress of the Enhanced HIPC Initiative agreement within 180 days of enactment and describe actions taken by countries to meet the agreement's conditions within 1 year. SEC. 5. A report on expanding debt relief to non-HIPC countries. Within 90 days of enactment, the Treasury Secretary must report to Congress on options and costs for expanding debt relief to poor countries not covered by the Enhanced HIPC Initiative. This includes burden-sharing among donor countries and institutions, as well as additional measures for debt sustainability after economic shocks or natural disasters. Consideration should be given to including poor countries with outstanding public debt in relief efforts. The Enhanced HIPC Initiative provides debt relief for heavily indebted poor countries with outstanding public debt exceeding a certain percentage of their annual revenues. The initiative was presented in the Report of G-7 Finance Ministers in 1999.
